sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: The latter motive alone is sufficient to excite my diligence; for, rest assured, dear Colonel, that whatever my cross stars design for me, I heartily wish your affairs may feel the influence of a propitious planet.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And be satisfied, Sir Charles, my happiness must be incomplete without yours; therefore let us hope the best on both sides. Exeunt severally.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Please to come this way, Sir, and Mrs. Busy will wait on you immediately.

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p: Very well, I shall attend the lady's leisure, child, la, la, la, (sings)

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: What an impudent fellow is this (aside) your honour won't be angry if I ask a question?

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p: No, not at all, my dear.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Pray did your honour ever hear of a brother of mine, one Thomas Ruelle, a soldier?

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p: No, child; nor was it at all likely I should, unless he had been in my own company; we officers seldom know any thing of the private, but that they are men, or look like such; we who bear commissions are entirely among ourselves, my dear, la, la, la, la (sings)

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha! I can hold no longer— well said captain Fusee; why, sirrah, could you imagine that fine cloaths, a bag wig, and quality airs, could hide that sweet gunpowder face from my knowledge?

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p: Pox o'this discerning jade, I shall infallibly be blown up (aside)

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Bless me, Captain! does your well-tried assurance fail you—pray what scheme, what military trick is your honour upon in this disguise?

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p: Since 'tis in vain to dissemble, I'll e'en tell you—my master wanting to get the old lady of this house off his hands, has put me into masquerade —I have had but one conference, and yet, by the help of mother Sly, want nothing but a parson to finish the affair.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Mighty well! and what then becomes of all your fine spun protestations to me, Mr. Saucebox?

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p: Why you know, Mrs. Ruelle, Pyramus and Thisbe never loved so well; but you was allways throwing dependance and poverty in my teeth, so I thought it high time to mend myself.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: A very fine come-off indeed; but I'll spoil your master's project, and your's, Mr. Impudence, I will, and discover all this moment.

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p: Nay, dear Ruelle, don't be so cruel as that neither.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p:
Dear Ruelle—not so much familiarity, puppy, you and your master are a couple of deceitful
forsworn rakehells, and ought to be exposed.

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p: What will nothing pacify you? nothing bridle that harmonious tongue?

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: No, wretch—not all the eloquence you have.

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p: Why then let my master speak—he desired me to present his compliments and this (gives a purse) the first I had no scruple to give, but the latter I thought to have saved.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Very honest indeed, noble captain, and like the rest of your tricks—let me see—hum— hum—ten guineas! why ah, these are compliments worth receiving, and shows the Colonel knows how to speak most feelingly—Yet, after all, must I not only lose so sweet a swain, but, as I have read in some play, be made myself the instrument? must I not only die, but plunge the dagger in my heart myself? this is indeed refining on calamity.

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p: Tender loving soul—I never thought her so fond as this—poor pretty soft rogue, let me kiss off thy tears.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Tears!—ha! ha! ha! ha! not so foolish as that neither, good Mr. Captain; and since your sincerity is brought to light, I'll show you that I was prepared against it.

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p: What does the jade mean?

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Mean, why I mean there's a sea captain, worth ten thousand pounds, my master's brother-in-law, whose heart I have so engaged, by helping him to some bowls of punch more than Sir Scrapeall allowed, that he has given me several kind glances, squeezed my hands almost to a jelly; and sworn, if I have a mind, he'll get a parson to splice us together to-morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p: Oh, snap him by all means; and when we have made the double match, you and I can be on better terms than ever, Mrs, Ruelle.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Stand off, jackanapes, and learn a proper distance to your betters—you and your old madam, must not put yourself on a footing with a real Captain's Lady; for my mess-mate, as he calls himself, though he's but a scurvy original, has the recommendation of a fine gilded frame to set him off—I shall so gall madam Fusee by taking place of her—for I am resolved, when once Mrs Starboard, to hold my own; to pay as many visits, to wear as fine cloaths, and have as grand a route as any city lady of them all.

sp.speaker: Fusee
sp.p: Hoity toity! what whirligigs fortune has planted in the wench's head already.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Captain, to your arms, the General's at hand. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p: Sblood! this mistress of mine has the same effect upon me that a labelled bottle has upon the stomach of a sick man;—but I must take the dose to cure the consumptive state of my pockets.
Captain, your very most humble servant.

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p: Madam, your eternal slave.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Lard, Captain, I am most infinitely concerned at the rudeness of having made you wait so long, and scarce know how to apologize; but my poor neighbour, Mrs. Dolefull, who has a sad fellow of a husband, came to consult me, and would not let me stir.

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p: Madam, though your absence to me is worse than riding the wooden horse, standing upon the picket, being tied up to the halberts, or even running the gantelope, upon so good-natured an occasion of delay as comforting a distressed neighbour, I must be not only satisfied, but pleased also at the beauty of your mind, as much as I am captivated with the beauty of your person, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Bless me, Sir, the force and delicacy of your compliment, makes me blush; I profess it does—yet who would ever trust a man after what my good friend Mrs. Sly related of the Colonel.

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p: Oh, name him not, madam, the young fellow is indeed plausible enough, but nothing of a soldier except the title—good friends, no merit; and as to gallantry, I know he makes it his business to boast of favours from the ladies.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, I defy him there, he could never boast of favours from me but in an honourable way—I don't flaunt about with profligate young fellows—no—I act with discretion—I have an unsullied character to support—ay, ay—if some forward flirting minx's of the age, would take half so much care of reputations as they do of complexions, there would not be such wicked and sensual doings.

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p: Very true, madam—ravishing sentiments —killing eyes—let me swear by the horrors of war, that though I have had my hat taken off by a four and twenty pounder; though my beard has been close singed by the flash of a cannon; tho' my teeth have been picked with bayonets; though a whole platoon of musquet balls has passed thro' my body; and though I have been three times blown up on the forlorn hope; yet never did my heart feel such palpitation as those charms have caused.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Oh dear, that's a most powerful impression —well, military gentlemen undergo great hardship—and I presume you are forced to kill people in your own defence, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p:
Certainly, madam—why now in the battle of—of—pshaw, pox, I have been in so many I don't know which it was—but this single arm demolished two French Marqui's, four Counts,
and above a dozen rank and file; but such bloody deeds are at an end; the promise of your fair hand, madam, has made me determine to throw up my commission.

sp.speaker: Mrs B.
sp.p: Obliging and tender to the last degree.

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p: But I shan't quit the service of my country entirely; I have a borough waiting for me, and I believe I shall accept of it—but, madam, say when shall the special licence, I have obtained, take effect.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: You are so zealous, Sir, but since you are determined e'en when you please.

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p: To-morrow morning then, my fair, the chaplain of our regiment shall attend, and I'll fly upon the wings of love to give you notice.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Dear Sir, you are so irresistably persuading —I shall certainly attend your call.

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p: Transporting sound!

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Bless me, I hear somebody coming; and I would keep all snug till things are done.

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p: Madam your words plant silence on my lips—ten thousand soft adieus.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: The same let me return—remember to-morrow Exeunt severally.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Colonel you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Your Ladyship's most obedient—pray, madam, was not that Lord Frederic who parted from you just now?

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: The same, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: So then here's anticipation against me. (aside)

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: I profess, Colonel, your coming has given me great pleasure; I began to almost despair of you; and my route would have been as insipid in your absence as a humdrum society of country-folks set to cards in a winter's evening.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Your Ladyship does me particular honour.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Well, after all this matrimony is a very sad thing — Siberia, I think you called it, did not you, Colonel?—notwithstanding which, my sister I believe will shortly travel to that desart clime—well, I hope she may find it a pleasanter spot than I have done.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Your sister, madam!

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Yes, truly—Lord Frederic, tho' his first visit, I find has hinted something that way, and my sister seems to have no objection.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! 'tis as I feared (aside) —this is a very sudden affair indeed, madam; but perhaps the match may not be so agreeable to Sir Scrapeall, and she can't marry without his consent.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: That's true, as you say, Colonel; but I believe his generous worship considers her as a saleable piece of goods, and would be glad to make a profitable affair of his consent.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That hint may be of use to me (aside) I should hardly have supposed your Ladyship's sister capable of so precipitate a compliance.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Why its a little out of the common course, but the impressions of love are lightning-winged, and very variable in their flight—witness those tender expressions, and the profusion of regard you have lavished upon me, Colonel— though any woman might be vain of the conquest, yet I never sought it: however I am really concerned you should be so much in love with me; but what can I possibly do?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A hopeful theme for my perplexity (aside) I am much debtor to your Ladyship's humanity, and must be content to sigh away my passion in absence.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p:
Absence; nay that looks like absolute despair —and despair is a very sad thing—I should grieve to be the cause of it—come, who
knows, Colonel, my agreeable lord and master can't live always, and when he's gone—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I wish I was gone with all my heart (aside) your Ladyship is so much in the right, that hope, tho' ever so distant, beams cheering rays; but if Lord Frederic should prevail, and blast—

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Lord Frederic! why you know Colonel, he addresses my sister.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: True, madam—he does so—I—I mistook —you'll excuse my confusion.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Poor man, I protest I pity him, I never saw him so much affected before, but I can't help the bewitching power of my eyes (aside) — nay, Colonel, be comforted, within the bounds of honour you may command me.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I can't in the least doubt your Ladyship's goodness, but ardent love is impatient of delay and fearful of defeat, therefore if your sister should resolve to check my wishes and favour a rival.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: My sister—you don't imagine she shall direct my choice.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No, madam—I did not mean that—but then in case—I say that if your Ladyship—a— oons, I don't know what to say.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: I see my staying does but perplex him the more—humanity instructs me to withdraw that he may have time to recover—well, Colonel, perhaps the company will compose your spirits and banish the train of impertinent thoughts which so busily intrude upon your quiet—I'll leave you with Lord Frederic till we sit down to cards, and I must positively insist upon your being of my party. Exit.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Pox o'party, cards, and company; every moment till I see Emmeline is torture.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p:
Well, Colonel, I must say you are a gentleman of very difficult taste, for, as I remember,
you told me that Emmeline was very middling in point of beauty, now I think her exquisitey charming.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: It may be so, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: may be so—nay it is so, Colonel— I profess myself the Lady's champion, my sword is devoted to her service as well as my heart, and I shall esteem any insinuation against her charms as high treason against the queen of beauty.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Your Lordship is very rapturous upon the occasion, and I don't doubt but your sword is as ready as you speak it; however, since matters are come so far, I must take the liberty to inform you that the Lady does not stand in need of your knight errantry, for I have professed my service, which having been accepted, I cannot now decline.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Hey day! why certainly we are got to cross purposes; what a person of Colonel Parapet's taste interfere with such an odd family as this, and devote himself to a young Lady who can only make a tolerable citizen's wife, on whom quality would sit very aukwardly? ha! ha! ha! ha! now I shall take the pains to polish this rough diamond.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Your Lordship is facetious, but to dash your lordship's hopes, know that a previous claim to the Lady's favour has been made by me, and countenanced by her, which I presume, my Lord, will put an end to your pretensions.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Put an end to my pretensions! as soon to my life, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: If that be your resolution, my Lord, I know but of one decision—you have, in appearance, an excellent sword, and I cannot doubt either your Lordship's skill or courage in the use of it.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p:
A very rational method of argument, truly; right military logic, and in regard of us young fellows may be salutary, our constitutions are too sanguine, and breathing a vain must be
useful, so I shan't baulk your resolution—come Sir. (draws.)

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Spoke with the generous pleasantry of true courage, and strict honour, it will be some pleasure, if I should fall, to fall by so brave a hand (draws)

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Let me warn you, Colonel, to keep at a distance; for there is not a man in England could stand long before me at close quarters.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You are particularly generous, my Lord, but I am prepared for all events.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Very well, Sir—come on then—yet hold—two points we have forgot: it won't be so decent to throw the family into confusion with our private animosity, and if in this combat the Lady's favourite, which ever it is, should fall, the conqueror will have no cause for trumph; so that being somewhat between hawk and buzzard, I think the Lady should be consulted; and if she declines an explanation we can but appeal to our swords at last.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: True, my Lord, and on that footing let me have the honour to call myself your Lordship's friend.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: I cordially embrace your proposal, and here the Lady comes most opportunely; if you'll open the case you shall have all the justice imaginable.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Colonel, your humble servant.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Madam, your most obedient—I am sorry there should be any occasion to desire an explanation of what, for particular reasons, I have endeavoured to conceal; but his Lordship informing me of acl he either has or intends to put in for your favour, I am under the necessity, madam, of requesting that you will do justice to the previous right I assert.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Right! Colonel!—I protest you astonish me! I am an entire stranger to the meaning of this formal address.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A stranger, madam!

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Quite so I assure you, Sir—you talk of right, and favour, and justice; but upon what cause, and between what parties I really cannot conceive.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: How, madam!

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: And if I did, not having been used to the law 'tis very probable I might not be able to decide; however the curiosity incident to my sex, induces me to request an explanation.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am thunderstruck!—is it possible, madam, you can need an explanation?

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Come, come, Colonel, this affected surprise, and these distant insinuations are unfair, I'll deal more candidly, and set the Lady right at onee—you must know, madam, that happening to mention the impression your charms have made upon my heart, this gentleman, my friend, declared that he had already preferred his addresses—

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: What! his addresses to me!

sp.speaker: L. Char.
sp.p: Yes, madam, and that you had received them most favourably.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Favourably—is it possible you could advance this, Colonel!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why, madam, did you not?

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: So upon this supposition, the colonel very kindly proposed his cutting my throat, or my cutting his; and if you had not appeared, madam, like the dove with the olive branch, I know not what might have been the consequence, for our resolutions seemed very terrible on both sides.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Your Lordship is very fanciful and merry; but I am not in a mood of temper to bear sneers at present.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p:
Nay now, Colonel, you are quite
too severe, that you'll neither allow me to love pattle nor laugh, ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Fire and fury!

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: So, so, so, now the mystery begins to clear up; and I perceive that what appeared rudeness is merely the unhappy effects of frenzy.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Sdeath! madam! frenzy?
Most certainly; could any thing else have introduced such romantic chimaers, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Madam, this affected ignorance of what you too well know, may prove insincerity, but cannot add to the reputation of candor and judgement —choice is undoubtedly free; but that choice once fixed, does not admit of alteration without some material reason.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Ay, there, Sir, I entirely come in with your opinion had any such choice been made: but I see you are quite too violent for argument, therefore I think it will be most prudent to retire.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Hold, madam.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Nay, no violence.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Sdeath! Sir, dare you interpose? (draws)

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Ah! (screams)

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Sheath your sword, Colonel, I shan't fight a lunatic, positively.

div3.stage: ENTER LADY BRAINLESS and MRS BUSY hastily.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Bless me what was the reason of that scream? —a sword drawn—ah, I shall certainly faint.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: The Colonel—my blood boils at the fellow.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: So, I shall have the whole crew upon me, (aside)

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: For heav'ns sake, Emmeline, what is the meaning of all this?

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p:
Only the Colonel, sister, who because I
would not confess being in love with him, very heroically intended to murther his Lordship.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: What! you in love with him?

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Yes, truly, and talks of having paid his addresses in form; asserts they were favourably received; and charges me with insincerity.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: What were his professions to make a cat's paw of me—my pride is hurt (aside)

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Ah, have a care child—he's a most dangerous fellow, he would have imposed upon me if he could.

sp.speaker: Col
sp.p: Yes, I shall have it now, and soundly too. (aside)

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: How, Sir! did you make love to my sister?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: To your sister, madam—

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Did not you sigh, and vow, and swear to me perjur'd wretch?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: To you!—

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: What was that your delicate taste?

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Where was your discretion.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Oons! I had no discretion to run myself into such a—

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Such a what, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, such a what?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why, such, such—'sdeath! no words can paint my condition.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Have not you attempted to asperse my sister?

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Did you not strive to delude me?

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: I find you are a general lover, Colonel, ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And what then, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. Brain
sp.p: Why then you are a deceitful treacherous hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: A base, designing, scurvy fellow.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am infinitely obliged to you, ladies.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: You are an inveigler of hearts.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: A breaker of vows.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: A vile betrayer.

sp.speaker: Mrs B.
sp.p: A monster of prey.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Mighty well, mighty well, truly; I have brought myself to a fine pass here; bubbled of my mistress, jeer'd by a coxcomb, baited like a bear by a couple of—well ladies I hope your lungs may be the better for this breathing whatever my ears may have suffered; for you, madam, who have so very short a memory, or such a weathercock heart, I have only to repent the knowledge of so much beauty and falshood; his facetious Lordship I may meet in a fitter time and place. (going.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What for you to begin again! 'sdeath! I'd sooner stand at the mouth of a charged cannon with a lighted match at the touch-hole. runs off.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Positively he shan't escape so easy. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Easy; no, no, he shall have t'other sasarara before he gets off. Exit.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha! let's follow and have a little more of it.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: With all my heart—tho' I almost begin to pity him. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Bless me, Sir! have a care—I'm afraid you'll fall.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p: No, no, my little pilot—you know the song—steddy, boys, steddy—thof I do carry too much canvas, and sail gunwale too, in a rolling sea I shall weather the gale—but strike my topsails, what are all these fresh-water passengers that are come aboard our ship, we sha'nt have stowage for them.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: You mean, Sir, the company that are coming to my Lady's route.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p: Route what's that?

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Why, Sir, a great many ladies and gentlemen who meet to play at cards all night.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p: An that be their trim, spring my bowsprit, if I were master of the vessel but I'd heave all such live lumber overboard—but what say you, my little pinace, to that same voyage I was talking about? an you like it I'll heave out a hawser of love, and take you in tow for the port of matrimony.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: La, Sir, I am afraid you only want to delude me; I have heard such strange things of you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p: Gentlemen! strike my flag not so bad as that neither—I'm a sailor, my heart of gold, not like one of your land pirates, who fight under false colours, and trade to horn-fair; we at sea stick to our sweethearts as we do to our ships, as long as they can swim—so if you like to swing in my hammock say the word; I'll cruize for a parson tomorrow morning, that shall splice us fast together as if we were at moorings with the best bower and cable of a first—

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: To be sure, Sir, you are very good; and I must own have won my heart; but I am afraid that Sir Scrapeall will be angry.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p: And what then? think you he's to have steering of me?—blow me up, Dick Starboard has not been so many leagues on the salt sea to be commanded by any land-lubber of them all.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, but your family may think it such a disgrace; and I would not have it said for the whole world—you know, Sir, I am but a waiting-woman.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p:
A waiting-woman! and what then? board me I was but a swabber myself, so there's family for family, ho! ho! ho!—mess 'tis not always safe to sail in your gilded ginger-bread pleasure-boats
—I like your model and trim; and look, d'ye see, if you'll chuse me master, I'll navigate you while there's compass, helm, and sea-store.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, I don't know what to say to you; you are so fond, and so engaging, and so sincere, that, excuse my blushes—I can't possibly refuse you any thing.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p: Why that's well said—this seals my commission (kisses her and stumbles forward) avast, avast, mess I shipp'd a head-sea on my poop there, and had much ado to come to rights again—well, my little frigate, I'll clear out of the canonical customhouse, and steer away with you for Merryland to-morrow morning—wind and weather permitting —mess thou shalt be rigg'd as fine, and swagger with any quality yacht of them all; and so, d'yee see, if you'll toss me up such another can of flip as I had just now, and make a trip with it to my hammock, when its my watch I'll do the same for you.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: Sir, I thought you might want something, so I kept the keys; Sir Scrapeall ordered Timothy to take them to bed, but I insisted on having them.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p: Well said, again, my little trimmer— run me ashore an it had not been for thee I might have lived on rope's ends and four small beer in this here ship; but choak my pumps, and scuttle my bottom, an she'll swim long—so many masters and never a steersman, she'll soon be on the shallows. (going jostles the side wing) So, so, bring the land marks to bear Dick Starboard, and double the head-lands, seaman like.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: There, Sir, you are at your chamber-door.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p:
Enough, enough, enough, I'll cast anchor
in Slumber-bay in less than half a glass.—Yo, ho, mess-mate, bear a hand, and don't forget the flip, d'ye hear. Exit.

div3.head: SCENE I.

sp.p: HA! ha! ha! ha! a pretty situation you had got into among the females; however, my discovery of the pretended Lord Frederic, has occasioned a considerable revolution in your countenance, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ay, and in my heart too, Sir Charles; but I am impatient to know the method of your discovery.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Know then I went in search of Lord Frederic, and being told he was gone to Lady Brainless's route, I followed; where I was so thoroughly mortified with an account of Lady Charlotte's marriage, that to collect my spirits, I retired and took a moon-light turn in the garden.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A proper place, and fit season, for melancholy reflection.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: I had not been long there when her masquerading Ladyship, and Emmeline, came down a neighbouring walk, enjoying aloud the perplexity they had given us; encouraged by the subject, I drew near, and received conviction that your rival is no other than my mistress, who concluded with remarking, that she thought they had played upon us sufficiently.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
Yes, truly, I think they have; so long that I began to be most horridly out of tune—but
prithee what could be at the bottom of this Quixote scheme?

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: To gain some assurance of our sincerity, which, after laughing at us a little, they seemed satisfied with.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Dear Sir Charles, let me embrace you, so prudent and spirited a design makes the little gipsies ten times dearer than ever—did you let them know the discovery?

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Not for the world—I hastened from the garden, joined the company some minutes before them, shook off all concern, was unusually gay, and gallanted Lady Betty Ombre so warmly, that poor Lord Charles was, in his turn, utterly discontented.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha! bravissimo! that was turning the tables upon them with strict justice; and I think it would not be amiss to have a little more of it

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: By all means, I sought you for that purpose, I am to call at Sir Scrapeall's this morning, and would have you drop in occasionally; for as the politicians play'd a double game into each others hands, it is but fit we should return like for like.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: With all my heart, it will be notable revenge; mischief on't had your discovery been made a little sooner it might have saved me five thousand pounds for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why in the heat of my passion, I went to the Knight, made known my passion for Emmeline, and offered half her fortune for his consent.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Ha!—a substantial compliment to the Lady, Colonel, but we must try to settle matters otherwise—but come the hour calls me to the citizen's —I'll lead the van, do you bring up the rear.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Fear not, I am ever punctual to my orders.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Dear Lady Charlotte, I am concerned to see your natural vivacity so much disconcerted by a slight supposition.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Slight supposition! alas, Emmeline, in your case you don't see with the eyes of love, else you would put another construction upon Sir Charles's behaviour.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: I admit there was something extraordinary; but the feelings he confessed when you told him of the intended marriage were strong and sincere; the gaiety he afterwards assumed was, if I judge right, a slight veil occasionally thrown over a gloomy heart.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: I can't think so—forced spirits are easily seen through, and such could never have carried him so far as to gallant that forward shallow piece of coquetry, Lady Betty.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: There, I must acknowledge, he was somewhat mysterious.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Would I had not taken this disguise, though it has been so far useful as to prove the sincerity of your lover, it has only purchased pain for me—I cannot blame Sir Charles—the fault is mine—I have acted like a foolish boy, who plays with and teizes a favourite bird, till breaking bondage, it takes wing never to be recalled; dear friend what step shall I take?

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: I would hope the best: still you know by appointment he will soon be here, sound him a little further and I dare believe he will yet fulfill my good opinion of him.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: I would indulge that hope, but strong doubts press forward to exclude it.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: I see him coming, and shall leave you to a private conference. Exit.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Sir Charles good morning—I have, according to promise, prepared a letter for my sister Charlotte, wherein I have enlarged upon your previous pretensions as much as possible.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: I am infinitely obliged to your Lordship; but upon second thought, I have determined not to offend Lady Charlotte by a visit.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Your resolution so warmly urged is very soon changed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Why, my Lord, upon cool deliberation, I think it better not to proceed any further in the affair; 'tis possible I might have interpreted the Lady's good nature too partially in my own favour; and as freedom of choice is undoubtedly just, it would be rude and cruel to interrupt her present scheme of happiness.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: You are of a very happy disposition, Sir Charles, that can so soon, and so coolly, reconcile an affair which seemed so interesting—

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I am tolerably philosophical in these matters; besides, to own the truth, I had, amongst other conversation, talked so much of love to Lady Charlotte that I fancied our hearts engaged when there was nothing meant, I believe, but a little fashionable gallantry.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
Sir Char.
sp.p: Nay, my Lord, she's too much a fine Lady to be in any danger that way—
Colonel Parrapet your most humble servant.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Sir Charles, yours: my Lord I kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: L. Char.
sp.p: Sir, I don't think your behaviour and our last parting admit of such familiarity.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Nay, my Lord, I came on purpose to solicit pardon; too free a glass had flustered my temper without the least intention of offence; acknowledgement of error is, I know, sufficient to a man of honour, but I must confess myself a little puzzled for an apology to this Lady.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Sir Charles, your servant—oh! the Colonel —may we hope that night and reflection, Sir, have given your thoughts a calm?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Most certainly, madam, and I hope your good nature will grant indulgence to unlimited confession, especially as I am come to make all attonement possible by offering any assistance whch may promote his Lordship's happiness and yours.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: So this swain is changed about too.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Your condescension is very forward, Sir, but I presume his Lordship can take care of his own happiness without your assistance.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Doubtless, madam—but if I could any way contribute—

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you are exceeding liberal and courtly in your professions and promises, I can witness that.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: How so madam? for by your own declaration I never had the honour of promising or professing to you —

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter, Sir, but I believe if you had, you are very capable of forswearing it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Oh dear madam, I am sorry you have so terrible an opinion of me; but I perceive this subject grows too interesting—adso, I had almost forgot to tell you, Sir Charles, that I met Lady Betty Ombre just now, and to use her own phrase, she dies till she sees you.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: I shall go distracted. (aside)

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Colonel I am obliged to you for delivering so kind a message; and from so accomplished a Lady; when your match with her sister Lady Frances is compleated; of friends we shall become brothers.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Confident! faithess wretches! (aside)

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That will be double pleasure; pray, madam, are you intimate with the family of the Ombres

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: I don't know, I can't tell—insolent tormenting man. (aside)

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Your Lordship will be happy in an acquaintance there—Sir Charles will introduce you, and if your Lordship's choice was not already fixed upon this Lady, there is a third sister who has a most bewitching pair of eyes.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: I can hold no longer.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: A very dangerous pair of sparklers, indeed, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Sir, you are a villain.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: And, Sir, you are the worst of villains.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Amazing!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Wonderful!

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Oh that I were a man for justice sake.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: And I too.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: And I too—what self betrayed, ha! ha! ha! ha! this is more than I expected, and hastens the comedy to a conclusion—what think you ladies, have we ballanced the account of perplexity or not?

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Ladies!

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: What do you mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Nay, never look strange; your scheme was well laid, and had not chance directed me to a moon-light walk in the garden last night, we might have continued food for mirth at the expence of our peace.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: I am glad its no worse. (aside)

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: I am so confus'd and so pleas'd, I know not what to say. (aside)

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: The palpitation of our hearts will, I hope, ladies, make this trespass on your patience appear excusable.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Well, gentlemen, since it is in vain to deny, I admit your discovery, and cannot but acknowledge your treatment has been founded on strict justice.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Spoke with your usual candour and generosity, lady Charlotte, and hence let mutual confidence ensue; as to you, madam, I have Sir Scrapeall's promise to make you mine.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: So! so! Here's counter-working— was it fair to undermine me; but pray how did you prevail upon the knight.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: By the rhetoric of five thousand pounds; that is, offering to surrender half the Lady's fortune.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Generous indeed!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And had it been twenty times as much I should have only thought it a fit sacrifice to so much merit.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: An excellent proof of disinterested love, Colonel—but you are outbid, for I proposed to take the Lady without any fortune at all; and am to have the honest Citizen's written consent within.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Contemptible reptile!

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha! upon my honour, Colonel, you have been fairly outsoldiered, beat at your own weapons.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: And poor I set up at auction to the best bidder.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! ha! even so, Emmeline; but all for the better, I hope—oh! I see Lady Brainless, I have some business with her in my
Lordly capacity and shall beg of you to retire.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: You command us madam.

div3.stage: Exeunt Emme. Sir Cha. and Col.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Now must I play a part severely kind in hopes of good effects, your Ladyship's most obedient.
My Lord, your humble servant,

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Your Ladyship had a bad run at cards last night.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Oh terrible! my Lord! it seemed as if fortune had determined to cross me.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Were not such things common, madam, in matters of chance, they would press hard upon patience—I think your Ladyship lost fifteen hundred pounds? one thousand to me, and five hundred to Lord Robert Whist?

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Thereabouts, I believe, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: I am sorry to urge your Ladyship; but being myself a good deal out of cash at present, and having a bill of eight hundred to pay this forenoon, should be obliged to you for the trifle depending between us.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Really, my Lord, your demand takes me rather at a disadvantage.

sp.speaker: L. Charl.
sp.p: You know, madam, it is not like the impertinent bill of a troublesome mechanic for work done, or goods delivered, it is a debt of honour; and such you know, takes place of all other payments among people of fashion.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: That's very true, my Lord, and I would always act up to the fashion, but inclination must give way where ability is totally wanting; and though Sir Scrapeall deals in cash I am almost as bare as if he was not worth a single shilling.

sp.speaker: L. Charl.
sp.p: If this be the case I find I ventured real against imaginary sums, and must therefore be more cautious of my company.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Really, my Lord, there is much less politeness in that inuendo than I should have expected from a man of fashion.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Politeness, madam, is very well upon particular occasions; but in gaming there is no such thing, we win of whom and when we can; like death, it cuts off all distinction of rank, relations and friends, and stakes must be paid, or persons exposed; but as your Ladyship is a fine woman matters should be made as easy as possible, and if—

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: If what, my Lord!

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: I presume there could not be much love in your match with Sir Scrapeall—I have conceived a passion, give it suitable return, and let the thousand pounds—

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Insolent man, no more; what part of my conduct, tho' perhaps ungarded, could encourage so gross an insult—gratify your malice, expose the sum due, and set me up the sport of laughing libertines, I'll bear all patiently, as the fruit and punishment of my own indiscretion, secure in this pleasing reflection, that tho' you publish my poverty you cannot taint my virtue.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Come, come, madam, Colonel Parapet would have received a gentler answer.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: No, my Lord, there you are mistaken also; for though that gentleman may have been allowed a particular intimacy, and may have improved or misconstrued appearances, he must be a consumate villain if ever he dropped a prejudicial insinuation; for let me say to you, to him, and all the world, that however I have dipped into follies, the vices of life could never make me a proselyte.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p:
'Tis as I always thought, dear Lady Brainless, these just and noble sentiments force off false appearances, and reveal me, instead of a gaming
Lord, your disinterested and inviolable friend Charlotte Bloom.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Lady Charlotte! why then this disguise! or why would friendship alarm such painful sensations.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: As to the motive of this appearance you shall know in due time—why I have wounded your delicate feeling was to awaken a sense of what you justly call follies, which have long obscured many valuable qualifications, and subjected you to the reproach of several who have lss real merit, but more external caution.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Dear Lady Charlotte, I shall be ever debtor to your kind opinion and friendly design; reflection tells me I have given too just cause for censure, yet not without some plea of justification.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: I am certain of it, your most disproportionate marriage, if not an entire excuse, is at least a powerful palliation.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Marriage; there you have said all at once, those who should have studied and judged better for my future happiness warmly urged the match; young and unexperienced I was, allured by the hopes of a title, and unlimited command; ever since I have been almost hourly rendered unhappy by the selfish and perverse temper of Sir Scrapeall, which has occasioned me to despise and cross him in every particular; and most of my extravagncies have been more calculated for killing time, than any pleasure—pity me, dear Charlotte, for I find my scheme of life widely different from what I wish, and yet in self defence I am obliged to follow it; when avarice, jealousy, and discord prevail at home, peace must be sought abroad.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: I have no reason to doubt your friendship —but tell me, did the Colonel use any freedom with my character?

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: No, upon my honour, what I hinted was from observation last night; and repeated to alarm you, tho' I sincerely believe you meant nothing.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Your interpretation, my friend, is kind and just; I own my horrid situation made me fond of his engaging conversation; and female vanity was flattered in some compliments he passed upon me, nothing more, I assure you, and yet, now I look back, such gallant trifling is like sporting on the unstedfast margin of a lucid stream, where while we admire the beautiful reflection in its liquid bosom, one false step hurries us to certain destruction.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Your similitude, my friend, is fancifully just; but we are too grave, Sir Charles, the Colonel and Emmeline are but in the next room, shall we join them and prattle away gloomy ideas.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Excuse me for the present, dear Lady Charlotte, the reflections you have awakened render my spirits unfit for conversation, therefore give me leave to retire—think for me, gentle friend, and if any means can be found to free from, or alleviate my bondage, I promise that future conduct shall prove my errors the effect of disagreeable circumstances; of a tormented, but not a dishonest heart. Exit.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: How good a heart may inadvertently be led into unfavourable appearance?

div3.stage: ENTER SIR CHARLES COLONEL and EMMELINE.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Knowing your design. Lady Charlotte, I ventured to make these gentlemen ear witnesses of the work of reformation, and they admire it vastly.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: I am glad of it; and hope you will all join to set her Ladyship free.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Sdeath! if there be no other method I'll chuck old cent. per cent. out of the window and her t liberty that way.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Come, come, I hope to effect it by some less furious means—I'll slep to him for a few minutes. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Hey-day! what have we here?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: As I live, mother Busy, and my man Fusee —married, I hope.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Sir Charles, your most humble servant —Emmeline, how dost do child?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And pray, madam, why am I left out of the catalogue of compliments.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: You! marry come up! indeed I wonder you have assurance to look me in the face after such behaviour, I should have been prettily off, indeed, if I had depended upon your fine speeches and palav'ring—I should have been a fine laughing truly, for all the coxcombs and gill flirts; but I'd have you know, Mr. Colonel, grown birds are not to be catched with chaff, no, no, I saw through all your designs.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Designs! madam! what could you see but the most faithful, the most ardent passion; but I suppose you tax me with inconstancy to justify your own falshood, and will give yourself away to blast all my hopes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Ah, that wheedling tongue, and that deceitful fae, if my virtue had not been impregnable, if I had not been as cold as ice to unlawful love, I don't know what might have been the consequence; but as I am not to be imposed upon; I know the world, and the difference of people— Captain Spontoon, my husband, has heard your baseness.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: How! husband!—ah cruel fair—are you then married.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p:
Yes, truly, Sir—perhaps you thought I could not get a match; but the Captain has discernment
—you might have made your market, Sir, but now 'tis too late.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Then, animosity aside, I wish you joy with all my heart; and hope Fusee may make you a good husband.

sp.speaker: Sir. Char. and Emme.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Fusee! and who's that pray?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A very honest fellow I assure you, madam, my servant that was, and your lord and master that is—how long have you been a Captain, Fusee?

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p: Not much above four and twenty hours, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Char. Col. and Emme.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs B.
sp.p: What can all this mean?—how, Sir! are you no Captain?

sp.speaker: Fusee
sp.p: No truly, not at present—but I will be one if you'll buy me a commission, my charming dear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Buy you a halter, my roguish dear.

sp.speaker: Sir Char. Col. and Emme.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: What am I tricked then? has neighbour Sly imposied on me?

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Oh no, madam, you are not to be imposed upon—you know the world, and the difference of people, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, hussy, must such a minx as you set up your face?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Nay, good madam, don't be in a passion, it discomposes your beauty—a bride, and frown —oh fie.

sp.speaker: Sir Char and Emme.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. B
sp.p: They provoke me so I don't know what to say or do—married to his servant! well you are pleased to be mighty merry, good folks— but I am not the first that has been deceived, nor shn't be the last—as for you, Colonel, I'll let your character be known; and this fellow I can be revenged of at any time; for if I throw myself into the river my jointure goes with me, so there's tit for tat, and bite for bite, he! he! he! runs off

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Follow your Lady, Fusee, she'll come too when she can't help herself.

sp.speaker: Fusee.
sp.p: I'll do what I can, Sir, for sake of the money; but if she should resolve upon a lover's leap e'en let her go, for truly I begin to think her service will prove harder duty than the brown musket and six-pence a day. Exit.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Well, madam, I think her insolence to you is pretty well repaid.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Thoroughly, as I could wish.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Nothing but strict justice on your own account, for she was most abominably troublesome —here comes Lady Charlotte and the Knight.

div3.stage: ENTER SIR SCRAPEALL and LADY CHARLOTTE.

sp.speaker: Sir Scr.
sp.p: Well, my Lord, upon signing the paper I sent you to peruse; you shall have my consent to marry her in writing.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Sir Scrapeall, your very humble servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Scr.
sp.p: How! my scarlet friend! what shall I say to him? (aside) your servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Well, Sir Scrapeall, the young Lady agrees to your consent in my favour.

sp.speaker: Sir Scr.
sp.p: Consent, Sir! ay, but—

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: How, Sir! have you been in treaty with another?

sp.speaker: Sir Scr.
sp.p: In treaty!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Another▪ why, Sir, did not you promise me your consent on abating half the Lady's fortune?

sp.speaker: L. Char.
sp.p: Nay, Colonel, but I abate the whole of her fortune.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Hey day! guardian! have you set me up to public sale?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I shall depend upon your word, Sir Scrapeall.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: And I shall positively insist upon my claim.

sp.speaker: Sir Scr.
sp.p:
You are very peremptory, gentlemen; but
suppose I won't consent to either, what then—as to you, Colonel, I don't think your fortune sufficient, and for you my Lord—keep our bargain and you shall have my consent to run away with her to Scotland. (aside)

sp.speaker: L. Char.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! a very honest and generous proposal, indeed, Sir Knight, but—a word in your ear, I have more occasion for a husband than a wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Scr.
sp.p: What! a husband!

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Yes Sir, that I'll testify.

sp.speaker: Sir Scr.
sp.p: How! are not you a Lord then?

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: No Sir, but I am a Lady by courtesy.

sp.speaker: Sir Scr.
sp.p: What the mischief, women turned into men; I have long scrupled to believe my ears, and now I shan't chuse to trust my eyes—well, Colonel, I shall consider your proposals.

sp.speaker: L Charlo.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, it shall be settled now, and—draw this way—not only give your consent but the Lady's whole fortune, or I'll make you repent it.

sp.speaker: Sir Scr.
sp.p: make me repent it—I defy you, Sir— madam, I mean.

sp.speaker: L Charlo.
sp.p: Softly, Sir, you sent me a paper to peruse.

sp.speaker: Sir rcr.
sp.p: And what then?

sp.speaker: L Charlo.
sp.p: You thought it was a release for that Lady's fortune; but listen to the title—directions for John Ringbolt, master of the ship Peggy, to run her ashore, she being insured at treble value—

sp.speaker: Sir Scr.
sp.p: Oh that blundering dog, my clerk aside well, Colonel, since I believe you'll make the girl a good husband, and she is willing, I shall give my consent.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, but it must be done in due form; and now as your Lady has many just causes of complaint, to prevent the trouble, scandal, and expence of a public divorce, she proposes a voluntary separation.

sp.speaker: Sir Scr.
sp.p: With all my heart, I'll resign all title to her—let her march as soon as she pleases.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: And take her whole fortune with her.

sp.speaker: Sir Scra.
sp.p: No, no, I did not say that neither.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: What I must consult the insurers, must I. (aside)

sp.speaker: Sir Scra.
sp.p: Oh—h—h—no, I'll do what you have a mind.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Well gentlemen and ladies, I call upon you as witnesses, that Sir Scrapeall agrees to a separation proposed by his Lady, and is so generous as to return her whole fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir Scra.
sp.p: Ay, all but the two thousand pounds her extravagance cost me.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: Oh, the insurers shall settle that point.

sp.speaker: Sir Scra.
sp.p: I shall certainly run mad—stark staring mad—if it was not for the hopes that brother Starboard will drink himself dead in a month, and make me his heir, I could never hold out.

sp.speaker: Starb
sp.p: (without) Who's aboard, yo, ho.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: What naval greeting's that?

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: By the harmony of expression it should be Sir Scrapeall's delicate brother-in-law.

div3.stage: ENTER STARBOARD and RUELLE, arm in arm.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p: (singing) And Moll, and Kate, and Nancy shall roll in loui's d'ors.—What cheer, what cheer, messmates? why brother Brainless, your poop always carries a signal of distress; what have you been in a gard gale since I saw you? mess, I have sailed through the channel of courtship twelve knots an hour, and made the harbour of matrimony with my little snow half a glass since.

sp.speaker: Sir Scra.
sp.p: How! what! not married, I hope?

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p:
I don't know what you call married, but I showed the parson a cocquet to clear out of the canonical custom-house; he clapped on his uniform,
read grace, spliced our hands, and launched us off to swing in a hammock together.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Bravely said, honest captain.

sp.speaker: Emme.
sp.p: Mrs. Ruelle I heartily wish you joy.

sp.speaker: Ruelle.
sp.p: I am obliged to you, madam.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p: Ay, ay, thank you, thank you, young woman, the same to you when you steer the like course.

sp.speaker: Sir Scra.
sp.p: I profess I am astonished!

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p: And why so, forsooth? is not she a tight built thing?

sp.speaker: Sir Scra.
sp.p: Well, since it is so, I desire you to pay me for the punch and eatables you and your followers have devoured, and the things you have broke.

sp.speaker: Starb.
sp.p: Pay! blow me up then this here ship of yours is no better than a bum-boat; so d'ye see, order us a good bucket of rumbo, make your bill, and we'll pay all together—a lght heart, &c. (sings)

sp.speaker: Sir Scra.
sp.p: Oh mercy on me! I must follow the mad bear to see he does no more mischief. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! what a rueful condition is the poor Knight in.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Deservedly—madam you have negotiated and distributed justice with most commendable impartiality.

sp.speaker: L. Charlo.
sp.p: The pleasing effects are amply rewarded, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Sir Cha.
sp.p: And now, my friend, it remains to perfect our own happiness, which has cost us so much anxiety in the pursuit.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
But will, in the hands of these ladies, more than repay it all; for how pleasing soever the irregular sallies of dissipation may be, I doubt not but we shall be perfectly and happily convinced
That human kind no equal bliss can prove,
To the chaste raptures of connubial love.
